context: The fraction of molecules that remains in the solution can partition between water to air phase. Thus, two analyte fluxes in the water-to-air and water-to-solid directions will be formed. The solution–solid and solution–air distribution processes operate simultaneously and the intensity of the compound fluxes depends on chemical nature of organic substances and of solid materials. Aromatic hydrocarbons of very low polarity (such as benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene) cannot form the strong hydrogen bridge bonds with water molecules. Therefore BTEX tend to escape from the aqueous solution. The aldehydes have a polar functional group (carbonyl group) and can react with water forming diols, which are accessible for hydrogen bonds. The hydration is more important for short chain n-aldehydes and decreases with chain length.
